--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> 
> >From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...>
> >
> >First, NEAT probably needs to be the one that decides who gets to
> >reproduce, who is elite, etc...  I think it might make more sense
for
> >you to use the scheme you describe except instead of trying to make
> >specific decisions about what "type" something is, try to assign
them
> >a meaninful fitness number, so NEAT can then take those and do
things
> >the way it likes.
> 
> Right, what I mean is to be able to utilize NEAT's decision-making
process 
> to help determine when further evaluations will no longer contribute
to the 
> outcome of the next generation, at which point further calculations
are just 
> wasted energy.
> 
> Here's an idea.  Suppose the Epoch code of NEAT were broken up into
parts 
> (if it isn't already).
> 
> // pseudo-code...
> Epoch()
> {
>     IdentifyBreedingSpecimens();
>     NextGeneration();
> }
> 
> Then, existing experiments that call Epoch() still work the same as
they 
> currently do.  But other experiments could call the 
> IdentifyBreedingSpecimens() code directly.  Suppose that code just
sets a 
> flag to true for all those that will be reproducing, and false for
those 
> that will not.  Then, it returns the number of specimens whose flag
changed 
> during the course of evaluation.  Thus, it is a non-zero value any
time the 
> list of who is selected for reproduction changes.  Then the
experiment can 
> use that value to help it know when it has performed 'enough'
evaluations to 
> have 'adequate' fitness values and is ready to move on to the next 
> generation.
> 
> Example:
> 
> steady = 0;
> do {
>     GetNextSample();
>     EvaluateNetworks();
>     if ( IdentifyBreedingSpecimens() )
>         steady = 0;  // something changed...keep evaluating
>     else
>         steady++;
> } while ( steady < 10 )
> NextGeneration();
> 
> My guess is that mine is not the only domain where this kind of
thing might 
> be handy.  Any sufficiently large domain would probably benefit. 
What do 
> you think?
> 

I'm not sure I'm understanding this idea correctly; can you go into a
little more detail on what makes IdentifyBreedingSpecimens() true? 
i.e. how do you know you have "enough" information to start breeding?
And if there is some criteria for this concept of enough, then why not
just apply the criteria directly to your fitness spread instead of
calling NEAT?  It seems that NEAT could just be called after you've
determined you have enough info.

The thing I'm not understanding is that NEAT just takes the top n% of
each species and lets them reproduce.  So no matter how many
evaluations you do or what the results are, NEAT will always choose
the same # of parents.  It's true that perhaps in some cases too many
networks will have the same fitness, but in that case NEAT will just
choose an arbitrary group as the mating pool.  So I'm not sure how
this fits into your idea that you will somehow accumulate a mating
pool incrementally?  Note also that different species are allowed to
produce different amounts of offspring, i.e. offspring are assigned on
a per-species basis.

Also note that you can't really make reproduction decisions without
all the fitness info, since the final fitnesses are adjusted by the
size of their respective species.  So the fitnesses are shared.  So if
you tried to decide who is going to reproduce before fitness sharing,
you would not get the benefit of fitness sharing.

Sorry if I may be misunderstanding- it's possible I'm answering the
wrong question!

ken
